The Measurement Object¶

The propagation of measurements, including the propagation of errors is at the heart of this package. This section will describe how Measurement objects are created as well as all the methods available to operate on Measurements.

class qexpy.error.Measurement(*args, name=None, units=None)[source]¶

Subclass of ExperimentalValue, specified by the user and treated as variables or arguments of functions when propagating error. Stores the mean and standard deviation of an experimentally measured value.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The name of the Measurement object.
  • units (str) – The units of the Measurement.

Properties¶

Measurements have a few properties that you can get and set. Each property has an example of how to get and set it.

Measurement.error_on_mean¶

The error on the mean of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the error on the mean of the Measurement object. Also updates the error on the Measurement.
Getter:Returns the error on the mean of the Measurement.
Type:float 
x = q.Measurement(5, 0)

x.error_on_mean = 0.5
print('Error on mean:', x.error_on_mean)

Error on mean: 0.5
Measurement.name¶

The name of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the name of the Measurement object.
Getter:Returns the name of the Measurement object.
Type:str 
x = q.Measurement(5, 0.2, name='mass')

x.name = 'length'
print(x)

length = 5.0 +/- 0.2
Measurement.relative_error¶

Gets the relative error (error/mean) of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the error of the Measurement to a fraction of it’s mean.
Getter:Returns the error as a fraction of the mean (ie. 0.1 corresponds to a 10% error).
Type:float 
x = q.Measurement(5, 0)

x.relative_error = 0.1
print(x)

5.0 +/- 0.5
Measurement.mean¶

The mean of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the mean of the Measurement.
Getter:Returns the mean of the Measurement.
Type:float 
x = q.Measurement(0, 1)

x.mean = 10
print(x)

10 +/- 1
Measurement.std¶

Gets the standard deviation of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the error of the Measurement.
Getter:Returns the error of the Measurement.
Type:float 
x = q.Measurement(5, 0)

x.std = 0.5
print(x)

5.0 +/- 0.5
Measurement.units¶

The units of a Measurement object.

Setter:Sets the units of the Measurement object.
Getter:Returns the name of the Measurement object.
Type:str 
x = q.Measurement(5, 0.2, name='length')

x.units = 'm'
print(x)

length = 5.0 +/- 0.2 [m]

Functions¶

Measurements also have a number of functions that can be used to get, set or display information about the Measurement object.

Measurement.get_covariance(y)¶

Returns the covariance of the object and a specified variable.

This funciton checks for the existance of a data array in each object and that the covariance of the two objects is not already specified. In each case, the covariance is returned, unless the data arrays are of different lengths or do not exist, in that case a covariance of zero is returned.

Parameters:y (Measurement) – The variable to get the covariance with respect to.
Returns:The covariance term between the two variables.
Return type:float 
x = q.Measurement([11, 12, 13])
y = q.Measurement([11, 12.1, 12.9])

print('xy covariance: ', x.get_covariance(y))

xy covariance:  0.95
Measurement.get_correlation(y)¶

Returns the correlation factor of two measurements.

Using the covariance, or finding the covariance if not defined, the correlation factor of two measurements is returned.

Parameters:y (Measurement) – The variable to get the covariance with respect to.
Returns:The correlation term between the two variables.
Return type:float 
x = q.Measurement([11, 12, 13])
y = q.Measurement([11, 12.4, 12.6])

print('xy correlation: ', x.get_correlation(y))

xy correlation:  0.917662935482
Measurement.get_data_array()¶

Returns the underlying data array used to create the Measurement object.

Returns:A python list of the data used to create the Measurement object.
Return type:list 
x = q.Measurement([11, 12, 13])

print(x.get_data_array())

[ 11.  12.  13.]
Measurement.get_derivative(variable=None)¶

Function to find the derivative of a measurement or measurement like object. By default, derivative is with respect to itself, which will always yeild 1. Operator acts by acessing the self.derivative dictionary and returning the value stored there under the specific variable inputted (ie. differentiating with respect to variable = ???)

Parameters:variable (Measurement) – The variable that the derivative is to be taken with respect to.
Returns:the numerical value of the derivative with respect to the variable
Return type:float 
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.5)
y = 2*(x**2)

print('dy/dx =', y.get_derivative(x))

dy/dx = 16.0
Measurement.get_units_str()¶

Gets the units of the associated Measurement.

Returns:The units of the Measurement.
Return type:str 
mass = q.Measurement(4, 0.5, units='kg')
accel = q.Measurement(9.8, 0.1, units='m/s^2')
force = mass*accel

print(force.get_units_str())

s^-2 kg^1 m^1
Measurement.print_deriv_error()¶

Prints the result of a derivative method error propagation.

The purpose of this method is to easily compare the results of a derivative propagation with whatever method is chosen.

q.set_sigfigs(4)
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.5)
y = q.Measurement(9.8, 0.1)
z = x**2*y

z.print_deriv_error()

156.80 +/- 39.23
Measurement.print_mc_error()¶

Prints the result of a Monte Carlo error propagation.

The purpose of this method is to easily compare the results of a Monte Carlo propagation with whatever method is chosen.

q.set_sigfigs(4)
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.5)
y = q.Measurement(9.8, 0.1)
z = x**2*y

z.print_mc_error()

159.90 +/- 39.04
Measurement.print_min_max_error()¶

Prints the result of a Min-Max method error propagation.

The purpose of this method is to easily compare the results of a Min-Max propagation with whatever method is chosen to confirm that the Min-Max is the upper bound of the error.

q.set_sigfigs(4)
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.5)
y = q.Measurement(9.8, 0.1)
z = x**2*y

z.print_min_max_error()

159.65 +/- 40.82
Measurement.rename(name=None, units=None)¶

Used to rename an object or change its units.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The new name of the Measurement.
  • units (str) – The new units of the Measurement.
 
mass = q.Measurement(4, 0.5, units='kg')
mass.rename(units='g', name='mass')

print(mass)

mass = 4.0 +/- 0.5 [g]
Measurement.set_correlation(y, factor)¶

Manually set the correlation between two quantities

Given a correlation factor, the covariance and correlation between two variables is added to both objects.

Parameters:
  • y (str) – The variable to set the correlation with respect to.
  • factor (float) – The correlation term between the two variables. Must be between -1 and 1 inclusive.
 
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.1, units='m')
y = q.Measurement(12, 0.2, units='m')
x.set_correlation(y, 0.8)

print(x.get_correlation(y))

0.8
Measurement.set_covariance(y, sigma_xy)¶

Manually set the covariance between two quantities

Given a covariance value, the covariance and correlation between two variables is added to both objects.

Parameters:
  • y (Measurement) – The variable to set the covariance with respect to.
  • sigma_xy (float) – The covariance term between the two variables.
 
x = q.Measurement(4, 0.1, units='m')
y = q.Measurement(12, 0.2, units='m')
x.set_covariance(y, 1.2)

print(x.get_covariance(y))

1.2
Measurement.show_error_contribution(color='#036564', title=None, output='inline')¶

Creates and shows a Bokeh or mpl plot of a histogram of the relative contribution of individual measurements to the variance of a calculated value.

Parameters:
  • color (str) – The color of the bars.
  • title (str) – The title that will appear at the top of the histogram.
  • output (str) – How the histogram is to be output. Can be ‘inline’ or ‘file’.
Returns:

The Plot object used to create the histogram.
Return type:

Plot

 
import qexpy as q

w = q.Measurement(0.0255, 0.0001, name='width')
t = q.Measurement(0.0050, 0.0001, name='thickness')
m = q.Measurement(0.156, 0.001, name='mass')
P = q.Measurement(6.867, 0, name='P')

E = 4*P/(m**2*w*t)

E.show_error_contribution(title='Error contribution')
Measurement.show_histogram(bins=50, color='#036564', title=None, output='inline')¶

Creates a histogram of the inputted data using Bokeh or mpl.

Parameters:
  • bins (int) – The number of bins for the histogram.
  • color (str) – The color of the bars.
  • title (str) – The title that will appear at the top of the histogram.
  • output (str) – How the histogram is to be output. Can be ‘inline’ or ‘file’.
Returns:

The Plot object used to create the histogram.
Return type:

Plot

 
import qexpy as q
import numpy as np

rand_norm = np.random.normal(10, 1, 1000)
x = q.Measurement(rand_norm)

x.show_histogram(title='Mean 10, std. 1 random normal')
Measurement.show_MC_histogram(bins=50, color='#036564', title=None, output='inline')¶

Creates and shows a Bokeh plot of a histogram of the values calculated by Monte Carlo error simulation.

Parameters:
  • bins (int) – The number of bins for the histogram.
  • color (str) – The color of the bars.
  • title (str) – The title that will appear at the top of the histogram.
  • output (str) – How the histogram is to be output. Can be ‘inline’ or ‘file’.
Returns:

The Plot object used to create the histogram.
Return type:

Plot

 
import qexpy as q

x = q.Measurement(10, 0.2)
y = q.Measurement(8, 0.4)
z = y**2*x

z.show_MC_histogram(title='Monte Carlo histogram')
